question:
What is the fiscal year period in India?

SSC MTS 10/05/2023 (Evening)
option_1: 1st April of a year to 31st March of the next upcoming year
option_2: 1st April to 31st December of the same year
option_3: 1st January to 31st December of the same year
option_4: 1st January of a year to 31st December of the next upcoming year
solution:
• The fiscal year in India starts on 1st April of a year and ends on 31st March of the next year.
  • This period is used for accounting, budgeting, and taxation purposes.
  • It helps the government and businesses to standardize their financial reporting and planning.
  • Therefore, option (a) is the correct answer.

Additional Information:

  • The fiscal year is also called the financial year in India.
  • It is different from the calendar year which runs from January to December.

question:
Goods which are of durable character which are used in the production process are called ___________________ .

SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Goods that have a durable character and are used repeatedly in the production process are known as capital goods.
  • These goods are not meant for direct consumption but are used to produce other goods and services.
  • Examples include machinery, tools, buildings, and equipment.
  • They help in increasing productive capacity and economic growth.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Consumption goods are goods used directly by consumers to satisfy their needs.
  • Veblen goods are luxury goods whose demand increases with price.
  • Complementary goods are goods that are used together, like printers and ink cartridges.

question:
Macroeconomics deals with which of the following studies?

I. Reasons behind the unemployment of resources

II. Determination of total output

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
option_3: Neither I nor II
option_4: Both I and II
solution:
• Macroeconomics studies the economy as a whole and focuses on broad aggregates.
  • It analyzes issues like unemployment of resources, inflation, economic growth, and total output.
  • The reasons behind the unemployment of resources (I) fall under macroeconomic analysis.
  • The determination of total output (II) or national income is also a key aspect of macroeconomics.
  • Hence, both statements are correct, making option (d) the right answer.

Additional Information:

  • Microeconomics, in contrast, studies individual units like households and firms.
  • Macroeconomics helps governments formulate policies for economic stability and growth.

question:
'Income and employment theory' is the other name for which branch of Economics?

SSC CHSL 16/10/2020 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The 'Income and employment theory' is another name for Macroeconomics.
  • Macroeconomics studies the overall economy, focusing on aggregate income, employment, inflation, and economic growth.
  • It examines how income levels and employment rates are determined and managed in an economy.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Microeconomics deals with individual consumers and firms, not the whole economy.
  • Public finance focuses on government revenue and expenditure.
  • International economics studies trade and financial relations between countries.

question:
_____________ is defined as the study of behavior of individual decision-making units, such as consumers, resource owners and firms.

SSC CHSL 09/10/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• The study of behavior of individual decision-making units like consumers, resource owners, and firms is called Microeconomics.
  • Microeconomics focuses on how these units make choices regarding allocation of limited resources.
  • It analyzes supply, demand, pricing, and production at an individual or firm level.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Macroeconomics studies the economy as a whole, not individual units.
  • Health economics deals with economic issues related to health care.
  • Econometrics applies statistical methods to economic data.

question:
John Maynard Keynes, best known for his economic theories (Keynesian theories), hailed from which country?

SSC CGL 04/03/2020 (Afternoon)
solution:
• John Maynard Keynes, famous for his Keynesian economic theories, was from England.
  • He revolutionized economics by advocating government intervention to manage economic cycles.
  • His ideas influenced macroeconomic policies worldwide.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Keynes's work gained prominence during the Great Depression.
  • His theories emphasize demand management to control unemployment and inflation.

question:
Depreciation is an annual allowance for the wear and tear of ___________ .

SSC CGL 05/03/2020 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Depreciation is the annual allowance made for the wear and tear of capital goods.
  • Capital goods include machinery, equipment, and buildings used in production.
  • It accounts for the reduction in value of these assets over time due to usage and obsolescence.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Depreciation is not applicable to finished goods, work in progress, or land.
  • Land is generally considered to have an indefinite life and does not depreciate.

question:
If the interest rate goes up, the demand for money will ________________ .

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (2nd shift)
option_1: First rise and then falls
solution:
• When the interest rate increases, the opportunity cost of holding money also rises because people can earn more interest by saving or investing.
  • Therefore, the demand for money decreases as people prefer to hold less cash and invest more.
  • Hence, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • This relationship is explained by the liquidity preference theory of money demand.
  • Higher interest rates discourage holding idle cash balances.

question:
The intervention of the government whether to expand demand or reduce it constitutes the ________________ .

SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• Government intervention to either expand or reduce demand in the economy is known as the stabilisation function.
  • This function aims to maintain economic stability by controlling inflation, unemployment, and growth fluctuations.
  • Hence, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Redistribution function relates to income and wealth distribution.
  • Expenditure function involves government spending decisions.
  • Transition function is not a standard economic term in this context.

question:
According to the law of demand, the consumer's demand for a good must be _______________ .

SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (1st Shift)
option_1: directly related to the supply of the good
option_2: inversely related to the price of the good
option_3: directly related to the price of the good
option_4: inversely related to the supply of the
solution:
• According to the law of demand, the consumer's demand for a good is inversely related to its price.
  • This means when the price of a good increases, the demand decreases, and when the price decreases, demand increases.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • This is a fundamental principle in economics describing consumer behavior.
  • The law of demand assumes all other factors remain constant (ceteris paribus).

question:
Law of Demand states that, there is a negative relationship between _______________ .

SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (1st Shift)
option_1: demand for a commodity and its supply
option_2: supply of a commodity and its price
option_3: tax on a commodity and its price
option_4: demand for a commodity and its price
solution:
• The Law of Demand states there is a negative (inverse) relationship between the demand for a commodity and its price.
  • When the price of a commodity increases, the demand for it decreases because consumers tend to buy less at higher prices.
  • Conversely, when the price decreases, demand increases as consumers are willing to buy more.
  • This relationship reflects basic consumer behavior and preferences.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • This law assumes all other factors remain constant (ceteris paribus).
  • It is a fundamental principle in economics used to understand market dynamics.

question:
Which of the following is not included in domestic income?

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (4th shift)
option_1: Income earned by the residents of the country
option_2: Income earned by the non-residents outside the country
option_3: Income earned by all the employees of the country
option_4: Profit of all the industries of the country
solution:
• Domestic income refers to all income generated within the countryâ€™s borders.
  • It includes income earned by residents of the country, wages of all employees, and profits from industries operating domestically.
  • However, income earned by non-residents outside the country is not included in domestic income because it is generated outside the domestic economy.
  • This distinction helps in accurately measuring the economic activity within the country.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Domestic income focuses on location of production rather than ownership of factors.
  • National income differs as it includes net factor income from abroad.

question:
Net Investment plus Depreciation gives an estimate of which of the following.

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Net Investment is the total investment after accounting for depreciation (wear and tear).
  • When you add Depreciation back to Net Investment, you get Gross Investment, which represents the total amount spent on new capital assets before subtracting depreciation.
  • Gross Investment includes investment in new capital as well as replacement of old capital.
  • Therefore, Net Investment + Depreciation = Gross Investment.
  • Hence, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Personal income relates to income received by individuals, not investments.
  • Gross Domestic Product (GDP) measures total output, not specifically investments.
  • Private investment refers only to investments by the private sector.

question:
What is Net National Product?

SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (2nd shift)
option_1: Net National Product is equal to Gross National Product plus depreciation
option_2: Net national product is equal to Gross National Product plus income of the foreigners
option_3: Net National Product is equal to Gross National Product
option_4: Net national product is equal to Gross National Product minus depreciation
solution:
• Net National Product (NNP) is calculated by subtracting depreciation (the value of capital consumed or worn out) from the Gross National Product (GNP).
  • Depreciation accounts for the reduction in value of capital goods over time.
  • Therefore, NNP represents the net value of goods and services produced by a country's residents after adjusting for capital consumption.
  • It provides a more accurate measure of the sustainable income of a nation compared to GNP.
  • Hence, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • GNP measures the total value of goods and services produced by residents regardless of location, without accounting for depreciation.
  • NNP is useful for policy making and understanding long-term economic health.

question:
GDP calculated at some constant set of prices is called _______________ .

SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• Real GDP is the Gross Domestic Product calculated using a constant set of prices, typically from a base year.
  • It adjusts for inflation or deflation, providing a more accurate measure of economic growth over time.
  • Real GDP reflects the true volume of goods and services produced, excluding price changes.
  • This helps in comparing economic output across different years without the distortion of price fluctuations.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Nominal GDP is calculated at current market prices without adjusting for inflation.
  • Real GDP is preferred for economic analysis and policy making.

question:
If we sum the gross value added of all the firms of the economy in a year, we get a measure of the value of the aggregate amount of goods and services produced by the economy in a year. Such an estimate is called _____________.

SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Afternoon)
option_2: National income at factor price
solution:
• When we sum the Gross Value Added (GVA) of all firms in the economy over a year, it gives us the total value of goods and services produced within the country.
  • This total value is known as the Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
  • GDP measures the economic output of a country irrespective of the ownership of the production factors.
  • It includes the value added at each stage of production across all industries.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Net National Product (NNP) accounts for depreciation and is measured at factor cost.
  • National income at factor price excludes indirect taxes.
  • Net Value Added (NVA) subtracts depreciation from GVA.

question:
The GDP estimation method measuring the aggregate value of factor payments is called _______________ .

SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The GDP estimation method that measures the aggregate value of factor payments (wages, rent, interest, and profits) is called the Income Method.
  • This method calculates GDP by summing all incomes earned by individuals and businesses in the production of goods and services.
  • It reflects how much income is generated from production rather than the value of output or expenditure.
  • The other methods are:
    • Product Method: Calculates GDP based on total output.
    • Value Added Method: Calculates GDP by summing value added at each production stage.
    • Expenditure Method: Calculates GDP by summing total expenditure on final goods and services.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The income method emphasizes factor payments as components of national income.
  • It helps in understanding income distribution in the economy.

question:
GDP is an indicator of a country's economy. What does 'D' in GDP stand for?

SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The letter 'D' in GDP stands for Domestic.
  • Gross Domestic Product measures the total value of goods and services produced within the borders of a country during a specific time period.
  • It reflects the economic activity happening inside the country, regardless of the nationality of the producers.
  • GDP is a key indicator used to assess the size and health of an economy.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • It differs from GNP (Gross National Product), which includes income from abroad.
  • GDP helps policymakers and economists understand economic growth and formulate policies.

question:
Which of the following options does NOT constitute a national income measurement method?

SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Credit Method is not a recognized method for measuring national income.
  • The main accepted methods for national income measurement are:
    • Product Method: Calculates national income by summing the value of all goods and services produced.
    • Income Method: Calculates national income by summing all incomes earned by factors of production.
    • Expenditure Method: Calculates national income by summing all expenditures on final goods and services.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct as it does not constitute a national income measurement method.

Additional Information:

  • The credit method may be used in banking or accounting but is unrelated to national income accounting.
  • Understanding these methods helps in evaluating a countryâ€™s economic performance accurately.

question:
In the given expression of GDP according to the expenditure method, which of the following represents the aggregate imports expenditure incurred by the economy?

C + I + G + X â€“ M

SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• In the GDP expenditure formula: C + I + G + X â€“ M,
    • C = Consumption expenditure
    • I = Investment expenditure
    • G = Government expenditure
    • X = Exports
    • M = Imports
  • Imports (M) represent the total value of goods and services bought from other countries.
  • Since GDP measures domestic production, imports are subtracted to avoid counting foreign production.
  • Therefore, M denotes the aggregate imports expenditure incurred by the economy.
  • Hence, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Exports (X) add to GDP as they represent domestic production sold abroad.
  • The net export component is (X â€“ M), which adjusts for trade balance.

question:
Which of the following is correct regarding the National Income?

I. Intermediate goods are not included in the calculation of national income.

II. Final goods are included in the calculation of national income.

SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (2nd Shift)
option_2: Neither I nor II
option_4: Both I and II
solution:
• Intermediate goods are goods used as inputs in the production of final goods and services; including them in national income would cause double counting.
  • Therefore, intermediate goods are excluded from the calculation of national income.
  • Final goods are goods that have completed the production process and are ready for consumption or investment, so their value is included in national income.
  • Both statements (I and II) correctly describe the treatment of goods in national income calculation.
  • Hence, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Excluding intermediate goods ensures that national income reflects the value of only final output produced.
  • This approach avoids inflating the measurement of economic activity.

question:
If there are N firms in the economy, each assigned with a serial number from 1 to N, then as per the product method, GDP can be written as ____________ .

SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (3rd Shift)
option_1: GVAâ‚ - GVA2 .... - GVAN
option_2: NVAâ‚ + NVAâ‚‚ â€¦. + NVAN
option_3: GVAâ‚ + GVA2 ..... + GVAN
option_4: GVAâ‚ + NVAâ‚‚ + GVA3 + NVA4 ....
solution:
• According to the product method of GDP calculation, GDP is the sum of the Gross Value Added (GVA) by all firms in the economy.
  • Each firm contributes its GVA, which is the value of output minus the value of intermediate goods used in production.
  • Summing GVAâ‚ + GVAâ‚‚ + ... + GVAN gives the total value added by all firms, representing the GDP.
  • Net Value Added (NVA) is GVA minus depreciation, so adding NVA alone wonâ€™t give the total GDP.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The product method focuses on the value created at each production stage, avoiding double counting.
  • GVA is a useful measure for understanding sectoral contributions to the economy.

question:
The value of GDP at the current prevailing prices is called _____________ .

SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The value of GDP calculated at the current prevailing market prices is called Nominal GDP.
  • It reflects the total monetary value of all goods and services produced within a country in a specific period, without adjusting for inflation.
  • Nominal GDP can increase either due to an increase in production or an increase in prices.
  • It is useful for understanding the current market value but not for comparing economic output over time.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Real GDP adjusts for inflation by using constant prices from a base year.
  • Nominal GDP can be misleading if inflation is high, hence real GDP is preferred for growth comparisons.

question:
The subject of the Study of Macroeconomics is based on which principle?

SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (1st Shift)
option_1: The principle of National Income
option_2: The principle of Consumer
option_3: The principle of Producer
option_4: The principle of Investment
solution:
• The study of Macroeconomics is primarily based on the principle of National Income.
  • It focuses on the aggregate behavior of the economy, including total income, output, employment, and inflation.
  • National income is a key concept in macroeconomics as it measures the total economic activity of a country.
  • The principle helps analyze economic performance and formulate fiscal and monetary policies.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Other principles like consumer, producer, and investment relate more to microeconomic or specific economic aspects.
  • Macroeconomics looks at the big picture of economic health and growth.

question:
Which of the following is NOT-a feature of National Income?

SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (1st Shift)
option_1: It is a macroeconomic concept
option_2: It is a flow concept
option_3: It is always expressed with reference to the financial year
option_4: It is included only in intermediate goods
solution:
• National Income is a macroeconomic concept that represents the total income earned by a countryâ€™s residents.
  • It is considered a flow concept, meaning it is measured over a period of time, usually a financial year.
  • National Income is always expressed with reference to the financial year to maintain consistency in economic analysis.
  • However, it does not include only intermediate goods; in fact, intermediate goods are excluded to avoid double counting.
  • Therefore, option (d) is not a feature of National Income and is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Intermediate goods are excluded because their value is already embedded in the final goods.
  • National Income measures the value of final goods and services produced.

question:
Which of the following organizations of the Government of India has been reporting the GDP at factor cost and at market prices?

SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Reserve Bank of India
option_2: National Sample Survey Organisation
solution:
• The National Statistics Office (NSO) of India is responsible for reporting GDP at both factor cost and market prices.
  • NSO collects, compiles, and publishes statistical data related to the economy, including national accounts.
  • It provides official estimates used by the government for policy making and economic analysis.
  • Other organizations like RBI, NSSO, and NITI Aayog have different roles but do not report GDP figures officially.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Factor cost refers to the cost of production excluding indirect taxes and including subsidies.
  • Market prices include taxes and exclude subsidies on products.

question:
Who among the following headed the National Income Committee?

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The National Income Committee appointed by the Government of India was headed by P.C. Mahalanobis.
  • P.C. Mahalanobis was a renowned Indian statistician and economist.
  • He played a key role in the development of Indiaâ€™s statistical system and economic planning.
  • Under his leadership, the committee laid down methodologies for estimating national income.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The committee was established in 1949 to standardize national income measurement.
  • Mahalanobis is also known for the Mahalanobis Distance in statistics and contributions to Indiaâ€™s Five-Year Plans.

question:
The GDP estimation method measuring the aggregate value of goods and services produced by the firms is called _______________ .

SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The GDP estimation method that measures the aggregate value of goods and services produced by firms is called the Product Method.
  • This method calculates GDP by summing the value added at each stage of production across all firms.
  • It focuses on production output rather than income or expenditure.
  • Other methods include:
    • Expenditure Method: sums total spending on final goods and services.
    • Income Method: sums all factor incomes earned in production.
    • Consumption Method: is not a standard GDP measurement method.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The product method helps avoid double counting by focusing on value added.
  • It is useful for understanding sector-wise contributions to GDP.

question:
Personal disposable income (PDI) can be defined as ________________ .

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
option_1: PI + Personal tax payments + Non-tax payments
option_2: PI + Personal tax payments - Non-tax payments
option_3: Pl - Personal tax payments - Non-tax payments
option_4: PI â€“ Personal tax payments + Non-tax payments
solution:
• Personal Disposable Income (PDI) is the income available to individuals after deducting personal taxes and non-tax payments from their personal income.
  • It represents the amount individuals have at their disposal to spend or save.
  • The correct formula is:

    PDI = Personal Income (PI) â€“ Personal Tax Payments â€“ Non-tax Payments.

  • This reflects the actual income that households can use freely.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Personal taxes include income tax, property tax, etc.
  • Non-tax payments could include fines, fees, and other compulsory payments.
  • PDI is important for analyzing consumer spending behavior.

question:
Which of the following identities is correct regarding GNP?

SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Morning)
option_1: GNP = GDP + Factor Income earned by the domestic factors of production employed in the rest of the world + Factor income earned by the factors of production of the rest of the world employed in the domestic economy
option_2: GNP = GDP - Factor income earned by the domestic factors of production employed in the rest of the world - Factor income earned by the factors of production of the rest of the world employed in the domestic economy
option_3: GNP = GDP + Factor income earned by the domestic factors of production employed in the rest of the world - Factor income earned by the factors of production of the rest of the world employed in the domestic economy
option_4: GNP = GDP - Factor income earned by the domestic factors of production employed in the rest of the world + Factor income earned by the factors of production of the rest of the world employed in the domestic economy
solution:
• Gross National Product (GNP) is calculated by adjusting the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) with net factor income from abroad.
  • The correct formula is:

    GNP = GDP + Factor income earned by domestic factors employed abroad â€“ Factor income earned by foreign factors employed domestically.

  • This accounts for income earned by residents from overseas and subtracts income earned by foreigners within the country.
  • Therefore, option (c) correctly represents this identity.

Additional Information:

  • GDP measures production within a country regardless of ownership.
  • GNP measures production by the residents of a country, regardless of location.

question:
GDP that takes into account the costs in terms of environmental pollution and exploitation of natural resources is called _____________ .

SSC CHSL 27/05/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Green GDP is the measure of a country's economic growth that accounts for environmental pollution and depletion of natural resources.
  • It adjusts the traditional GDP by subtracting the costs associated with environmental degradation.
  • This provides a more sustainable and realistic picture of economic progress.
  • Other types like white, brown, or blue GDP are not standard terms in this context.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Green GDP is important for assessing the impact of economic activities on the environment.
  • It encourages policies aimed at sustainable development and environmental protection.

question:
NDP at FC = GDP at FC minus _______________ .

SSC CHSL 30/05/2022 (Morning)
option_3: net factor income from abroad
solution:
• Net Domestic Product at Factor Cost (NDP at FC) is calculated by subtracting depreciation (also called capital consumption allowance) from Gross Domestic Product at Factor Cost (GDP at FC).
  • Depreciation accounts for the wear and tear or consumption of fixed capital during the production process.
  • This adjustment gives the net value of goods and services produced, reflecting the sustainable economic output.
  • Other options like indirect taxes, net factor income from abroad, and subsidies are not subtracted to calculate NDP at FC.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Factor cost means the value of output excluding indirect taxes but including subsidies.
  • NDP is a better measure than GDP for assessing economic health over time.

question:
Which of the following angles of the flow of factor payments forms the basis to estimate the national income?

SSC CHSL 30/05/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Income Distribution Angle of factor payments forms the basis for estimating National Income.
  • It looks at how income generated from production is distributed among the factors of production â€” wages to labor, rent to land, interest to capital, and profits to entrepreneurship.
  • This angle helps in aggregating all factor incomes to arrive at the national income figure.
  • Other angles like consumption, expenditure, and production relate to different approaches but are not the primary basis for national income estimation.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The income method of national income estimation focuses on factor payments.
  • Understanding income distribution is crucial for economic policy and planning.

question:
To combat inflation, what is the usual monetary policy stance adopted?

SSC CHSL 03/06/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• To combat inflation, the usual monetary policy stance adopted is Hawkish.
  • A hawkish stance means the central bank tightens monetary policy by increasing interest rates or reducing money supply to control inflation.
  • This approach aims to reduce spending and borrowing, thereby slowing down price rises.
  • Dovish stance, on the other hand, focuses on stimulating growth with lower interest rates and is used when inflation is low.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Hawkish policies may slow economic growth but help maintain price stability.
  • Central banks balance between hawkish and dovish stances based on economic conditions.

question:
Which of the following is true?

SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Morning)
option_1: Gross Domestic Product + Depreciation = Gross National Product
option_2: Gross Domestic Product + Depreciation = Net Domestic Product
option_3: Gross Domestic Product â€“ Depreciation = Gross National Product
option_4: Gross Domestic Product â€“ Depreciation = Net Domestic Product
solution:
• The correct relationship is:

    Gross Domestic Product (GDP) â€“ Depreciation = Net Domestic Product (NDP).

  • Depreciation refers to the wear and tear or consumption of fixed capital during the production process.
  • Subtracting depreciation from GDP gives NDP, which represents the net value of goods and services produced.
  • Options involving addition of depreciation or relating GDP directly to GNP are incorrect.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • NDP is a better indicator of sustainable production than GDP.
  • Gross National Product (GNP) differs from GDP by accounting for net factor income from abroad.

question:
The value of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of India is published by PIB in ____________ .

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Morning)
solution:
• The value of Indiaâ€™s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is officially published by the Press Information Bureau (PIB) in Indian Rupees (INR).
  • Since GDP represents the economic output of India, it is expressed in the national currency for domestic use and policy formulation.
  • Using the local currency makes the data more relevant and easier to interpret for Indian stakeholders.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • For international comparisons, GDP figures may be converted into US Dollars or other currencies.
  • PIB is the nodal agency for disseminating official government data and information.

question:
Which among the following is included in the gross domestic product?

SSC MTS 18/10/2021 (Morning)
option_1: Sale of used goods
option_2: Bartered goods and services
option_3: Sales of final goods
solution:
• Gross Domestic Product (GDP) includes the sales of final goods and services produced within a country during a given period.
  • Final goods are those that have completed the production process and are ready for consumption or investment.
  • Used goods sales are not included because they were counted in GDP when first sold.
  • Bartered goods and services are not always recorded in official GDP as they may not involve monetary transactions.
  • Transfer payments (like pensions, subsidies) are financial transfers, not payments for goods or services, so they are excluded.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • GDP avoids double counting by only including final goods, not intermediate or used goods.
  • Transfer payments affect income distribution but not production.

question:
Which of the following best defines Net National Income?

SSC CHSL 14/10/2020 (Morning)
solution:
• Net National Income (NNI) is defined as Gross National Product (GNP) minus depreciation.
  • Depreciation accounts for the wear and tear or consumption of capital goods during the production process.
  • NNI reflects the actual income available to the nation after replacing the worn-out capital.
  • It gives a more accurate picture of economic welfare compared to GNP.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • GNP measures the total income earned by a country's residents, including income from abroad, without adjusting for capital consumption.
  • NNI helps in understanding the sustainable income level of a nation.

question:
In India the National Income is calculated by which of the following?

MPPSC, 2012
option_4: Reserve Bank of India
solution:
• In India, the National Income is calculated and published by the Central Statistics Office (CSO).
  • CSO is responsible for collecting, compiling, and disseminating statistical data related to the economy, including national accounts.
  • It provides official estimates used by the government for policy making and economic analysis.
  • Other agencies like Planning Commission (now NITI Aayog), Ministry of Finance, and RBI have different roles but do not calculate National Income.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The CSO operates under the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI).
  • Accurate national income data is essential for economic planning and development.

question:

UPPSC (Mains), 2013
solution:

  • Subsequent economists like R.C. Dutt, V.K.R.V. Rao, and D.R. Gadgil contributed to refining national income measurements.

question:
National income of a country for a given period of time-

IAS, 2013
option_1: Will be equal to the total value of goods and services produced by citizens
option_2: Will be equal to the sum of total consumption and investment expenditure
option_3: Will be equal to the sum of personal income of all individuals
option_4: Will be equal to the monetary value of final goods and services produced
solution:
• The National Income of a country for a given period is defined as the total value of goods and services produced by the citizens of that country.
  • It includes income earned by residents both domestically and abroad.
  • This measure focuses on the ownership of production factors rather than the location of production.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • National Income differs from GDP, which measures production within the country irrespective of ownership.
  • It is a key indicator to assess the economic well-being of a nationâ€™s citizens.

question:

1AS - 2000
solution:
• The per capita income in India in 1867-68, estimated at Rs. 20, was first determined by Dadabhai Naoroji.
  • He was a pioneer in studying Indiaâ€™s economic conditions during British rule.
  • His work highlighted the economic exploitation of India and laid the foundation for economic nationalism.

Additional Information:

  • Dadabhai Naoroji is known as the "Grand Old Man of India" and was the first Indian to be elected to the British Parliament.
  • His estimates were among the earliest systematic attempts to analyze Indiaâ€™s economy.

question:
The term 'national income' represents-

IAS, 2001
option_1: Gross national product at market prices, less depreciation
option_2: Gross national product at market prices, less depreciation, plus net factor income from abroad
option_3: Gross national product at market prices, less depreciation and indirect taxes, plus subsidies
option_4: Gross national product at market prices, less net factor income from abroad
solution:
• The term 'National Income' represents the Gross National Product (GNP) at market prices, minus depreciation and indirect taxes, plus subsidies.
  • This definition accounts for the net value of production after adjusting for capital consumption (depreciation) and government tax policies.
  • Indirect taxes increase market prices but do not reflect actual income, so they are subtracted.
  • Subsidies reduce the cost of production, so they are added back.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • National Income measures the net real income earned by a country's residents.
  • It is a key indicator for economic welfare and policy formulation.

question:
The standard of living in a country reflects-

UPPSC (Mains), 2013
option_1: In proportion to poverty
solution:
• The standard of living in a country is best reflected by its per capita income.
  • Per capita income measures the average income earned per person in a country, indicating the general economic well-being of its citizens.
  • Higher per capita income usually suggests better access to goods, services, education, and healthcare, which improve living standards.
  • Other factors like poverty, national income, and unemployment rate also influence living standards but per capita income is the most direct indicator.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Standard of living encompasses both material and non-material aspects like quality of life.
  • Policymakers use per capita income to assess and compare economic development.

question:
Which of the following is not a feature of the Indian economy?

UPPSC (Mains), 2004
option_1: Low efficiency of labour
option_2: Low per capita income
option_3: Low rate of capital formation
option_4: Lack of natural resources
solution:
• The Indian economy has several notable features such as low efficiency of labor, low per capita income, and a low rate of capital formation.
  • However, lack of natural resources is not a feature of the Indian economy, as India is rich in a variety of natural resources like coal, iron ore, minerals, and agricultural land.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct as it is not a feature of the Indian economy.

Additional Information:

  • Despite abundant natural resources, issues like inefficient utilization and infrastructure constraints affect economic growth.
  • Addressing labor efficiency and capital formation remains crucial for Indiaâ€™s development.

question:
The Indian economy is characterised by-

UP Lower Sub (Pre), 2004

Predominance of agriculture

2. Predominance of industry

3. Low per capita income

4. Mass unemployment

Select the correct answer from the code given below :
option_1: (a) 1 and 2
option_2: (b) 1, 2 and 3

    1. Predominance of agriculture, as a large part of the population depends on agriculture for livelihood.
    2. Low per capita income, indicating that average income per person is relatively low.
    3. Mass unemployment, which reflects the challenge of providing jobs to a large and growing workforce.

question: Indian economy can be described as-
option_1: A backward and stagnant economy
solution:
• The Indian economy is best described as a developing economy.
  • It is characterized by rapid growth in sectors like industry and services, but still faces challenges such as poverty, unemployment, and infrastructure deficits.
  • Unlike developed economies, India is in the process of industrialization and improving living standards.
  • The economy shows dynamic changes and efforts towards modernization and growth.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Developing economies are marked by lower per capita income compared to developed nations.
  • India continues to work on improving health, education, and economic infrastructure.

question:
Economic growth in country X will necessarily occur if-

IAS, 2013
option_1: There is technological progress in the world economy
option_2: There is population growth in X
option_3: There is capital formation in X
option_4: The volume of trade in the world economy increases
solution:
• Economic growth in a country fundamentally depends on capital formation (investment in physical assets like machinery, infrastructure, etc.).
  • Capital formation increases the productive capacity of the economy, leading to higher output and growth.
  • Technological progress and trade growth can support economic growth but do not guarantee it without capital accumulation.
  • Population growth alone does not ensure growth and can sometimes strain resources.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Capital formation is crucial for industrial expansion and infrastructure development.
  • Sustained economic growth requires a combination of capital, technology, and human resources.

question: Which of the following best describes Gross Domestic Product (GDP)?
option_1: Total income earned by a country's residents, including income from abroad
option_2: Total market value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a given period
option_3: Total value of goods imported into a country in a year
option_4: Net income earned from foreign investments only
solution:
• Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is best described as the total market value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a given period.
  • It measures the economic activity within the geographical boundaries of the country, regardless of who owns the production factors.
  • GDP includes only the value of final goods and services to avoid double counting.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Option (a) describes Gross National Product (GNP).
  • Imports (option c) are not included in GDP, rather subtracted if using expenditure approach.
  • Net income from foreign investments (option d) relates to net factor income, part of GNP calculations.
